NEGDITOTLCN.sourceOrganization: World Bank staff calculations based on World Development Indicators data.
NEGDITOTLCN.name: Total Investment, current LCU, millions
NEGDITOTLCN.sourceNote: Total Investment consists of outlays on additions to the fixed assets of the economy plus net changes in the level of inventories. Fixed assets include land improvements (fences, ditches, drains, and so on); plant, machinery, and equipment purchases; and the construction of roads, railways, and the like, including schools, offices, hospitals, private residential dwellings, and commercial and industrial buildings. Inventories are stocks of goods held by firms to meet temporary or unexpected fluctuations in production or sales, and "work in progress." According to the 1993 SNA, net acquisitions of valuables are also considered capital formation. Data are in current LCU millions.

DXGSRMRCHSAXD.sourceOrganization: World Bank staff calculations based on Datastream and IMF International Finance Statistics data.
DXGSRMRCHSAXD.name: Exports Merchandise, Customs, Price, US$, seas. adj.
DXGSRMRCHSAXD.sourceNote: The price index of Merchandise (goods) exports,  free on board (f.o.b.), in US$ seasonally adjusted.

REER.sourceOrganization: World Bank staff calculations based on Datastream and IMF International Finance Statistics data.
REER.name: Real Effective Exchange Rate
REER.sourceNote: Real effective exchange rate is the nominal effective exchange rate (a measure of the value of a currency against a weighted average of several foreign currencies) divided by a price deflator or index of costs.

NEGDITOTLCD.sourceOrganization: World Bank staff calculations based on World Development Indicators data.
NEGDITOTLCD.name: Total Investment, current US$, millions
NEGDITOTLCD.sourceNote: Total Investment consists of outlays on additions to the fixed assets of the economy plus net changes in the level of inventories. Fixed assets include land improvements (fences, ditches, drains, and so on); plant, machinery, and equipment purchases; and the construction of roads, railways, and the like, including schools, offices, hospitals, private residential dwellings, and commercial and industrial buildings. Inventories are stocks of goods held by firms to meet temporary or unexpected fluctuations in production or sales, and "work in progress." According to the 1993 SNA, net acquisitions of valuables are also considered capital formation. Data are in current US$ millions.

NEGDITOTLKD.sourceOrganization: World Bank staff calculations based on World Development Indicators data.
NEGDITOTLKD.name: Total Investment, constant US$, millions
NEGDITOTLKD.sourceNote: Total Investment consists of outlays on additions to the fixed assets of the economy plus net changes in the level of inventories. Fixed assets include land improvements (fences, ditches, drains, and so on); plant, machinery, and equipment purchases; and the construction of roads, railways, and the like, including schools, offices, hospitals, private residential dwellings, and commercial and industrial buildings. Inventories are stocks of goods held by firms to meet temporary or unexpected fluctuations in production or sales, and "work in progress." According to the 1993 SNA, net acquisitions of valuables are also considered capital formation. Data are in constant US$ millions.  The base year is 2005.

NECONGOVTKN.sourceOrganization: World Bank staff calculations based on World Development Indicators data.
NECONGOVTKN.name: Government Consumption, constant LCU, millions
NECONGOVTKN.sourceNote: Government consumption (formerly general government consumption) includes all government current expenditures for purchases of goods and services (including compensation of employees). It also includes most expenditures on national defense and security, but excludes government military expenditures that are part of government capital formation. Data are in constant LCU, millions. The base year varies by country.

NEGDITOTLKN.sourceOrganization: World Bank staff calculations based on World Development Indicators data.
NEGDITOTLKN.name: Total Investment, constant LCU, millions
NEGDITOTLKN.sourceNote: Total Investment consists of outlays on additions to the fixed assets of the economy plus net changes in the level of inventories. Fixed assets include land improvements (fences, ditches, drains, and so on); plant, machinery, and equipment purchases; and the construction of roads, railways, and the like, including schools, offices, hospitals, private residential dwellings, and commercial and industrial buildings. Inventories are stocks of goods held by firms to meet temporary or unexpected fluctuations in production or sales, and "work in progress." According to the 1993 SNA, net acquisitions of valuables are also considered capital formation. Data are in constant LCU millions. The base year varies by country.

BNGSRNFSVCD.name: Services Balance, BOP, current US$, millions
BNGSRNFSVCD.sourceNote: Service Balance is the sum of exports minus imports of services. Data is in current US$, millions.

NECONGOVTKD.sourceOrganization: World Bank staff calculations based on World Development Indicators data.
NECONGOVTKD.name: Government Consumption, constant US$, millions
NECONGOVTKD.sourceNote: Government consumption (formerly general government consumption) includes all government current expenditures for purchases of goods and services (including compensation of employees). It also includes most expenditures on national defense and security, but excludes government military expenditures that are part of government capital formation. Data are in constant US$, millions.  The base year is 2005.

BNGSRNFSVKD.name: Services Balance, BOP, constant US$, millions
BNGSRNFSVKD.sourceNote: Trade Balance is the sum of exports minus imports of services. Data is in constant US$, millions.

DSTKMKTXD.sourceOrganization: World Bank staff calculations based on Datastream and IMF International Finance Statistics data.
DSTKMKTXD.name: Stock Markets, US$
DSTKMKTXD.sourceNote: Local equity market index valued in US$ terms

NECONGOVTCD.sourceOrganization: World Bank staff calculations based on World Development Indicators data.
NECONGOVTCD.name: Government Consumption, current US$, millions
NECONGOVTCD.sourceNote: Government consumption (formerly general government consumption) includes all government current expenditures for purchases of goods and services (including compensation of employees). It also includes most expenditures on national defense and security, but excludes government military expenditures that are part of government capital formation. Data are in current US$, millions

DPANUSSPB.sourceOrganization: World Bank staff calculations based on Datastream and IMF International Finance Statistics data.
DPANUSSPB.name: Exchange rate, new LCU per USD extended backward, period average
DPANUSSPB.sourceNote: Local currency units (LCU) per U.S. dollar, with values prior to the currency's introduction presented in the new currency's terms

NECONGOVTCN.sourceOrganization: World Bank staff calculations based on World Development Indicators data.
NECONGOVTCN.name: Government Consumption, current LCU, millions
NECONGOVTCN.sourceNote: Government consumption (formerly general government consumption) includes all government current expenditures for purchases of goods and services (including compensation of employees). It also includes most expenditures on national defense and security, but excludes government military expenditures that are part of government capital formation. Data are in current LCU, millions

DPANUSSPF.sourceOrganization: World Bank staff calculations based on Datastream and IMF International Finance Statistics data.
DPANUSSPF.name: Exchange rate, old LCU per USD extended forward, period average
DPANUSSPF.sourceNote: Local currency units (LCU) per U.S. dollar, with values after a new currency's introduction presented in the old currency's terms

NEGDIFTOTXN.sourceOrganization: World Bank staff calculations based on World Development Indicators data.
NEGDIFTOTXN.name: Fixed Investment deflator, LCU
NEGDIFTOTXN.sourceNote: The Fixed Investment implicit deflator is the ratio of Fixed Investment  in current local currency to Fixed Investment in constant local currency. The base year varies by country.

NYGDPGAP_.sourceOrganization: World Bank staff calculations based on World Development Indicators data.
NYGDPGAP_.name: Output gap, %
NYGDPGAP_.sourceNote: The output gap is calculated as actual GDP less potential GDP as a percent of potential GDP. Potential GDP is  the estimated level of total output when the economy is operating at natural rate of unemployment. Estimates of output gaps are subject to a significant margin of uncertainty.

LIBOR3M.sourceOrganization: World Bank staff calculations based on Datastream data.
LIBOR3M.name: London Interbank Offered 3-month rates (LIBOR)
LIBOR3M.sourceNote: LIBOR stands for London Interbank Offered Rate. It's the rate of interest at which banks offer to lend money to one another in the wholesale money markets in London. It is a standard financial index used in international capital markets. The data is for the 3 Month LIBOR rate.

NECONPRVTKD.sourceOrganization: World Bank staff calculations based on World Development Indicators data.
NECONPRVTKD.name: Private Consumption, constant US$, millions
NECONPRVTKD.sourceNote: Private Consumption is the market value of all goods and services, including durable products (such as cars, washing machines, and home computers), purchased by households. It excludes purchases of dwellings but includes imputed rent for owner-occupied dwellings. It also includes payments and fees to governments to obtain permits and licenses. Here, household consumption expenditure includes the expenditures of nonprofit institutions serving households, even when reported separately by the country. Data are in constant US$, millions.  The base year is 2005.

CPTOTNSXN.sourceOrganization: World Bank staff calculations based on Datastream data.
CPTOTNSXN.name: CPI Price, nominal
CPTOTNSXN.sourceNote: The consumer price index reflects the change in prices for the average consumer of a constant basket of consumer goods. Data is not seasonally adjusted.

BXGSRMRCHXD.name: Exports Merchandise, BOP, deflator, US$
BXGSRMRCHXD.sourceNote: The Exports Merchandise implicit deflator is the ratio of Exports Merchandise  in current local currency to Exports Merchandise  in constant local currency. The base year varies by country.

BMGSRMRCHKD.name: Imports Merchandise, BOP, constant US$, millions
BMGSRMRCHKD.sourceNote: Merchandise imports show the cost, insurance & freight (c.i.f.)  value of goods received from the rest of the world valued in constant U.S. dollars, millions.

CPTOTSAXNZGY.sourceOrganization: World Bank staff calculations based on Datastream data.
CPTOTSAXNZGY.name: CPI Price, % y-o-y, nominal, seas. adj.
CPTOTSAXNZGY.sourceNote: The consumer price index reflects the change in prices for the average consumer of a constant basket of consumer goods. Data is in nominal percentage terms, measured on a year-on-year basis, and seasonally adjusted.

BMGSRMRCHCD.name: Imports Merchandise, BOP, current US$, millions
BMGSRMRCHCD.sourceNote: Merchandise imports show the cost, insurance & freight (c.i.f.) value of goods received from the rest of the world valued in current U.S. dollars, millions.

DXGSRMRCHSACD.sourceOrganization: World Bank staff calculations based on Datastream and IMF International Finance Statistics data.
DXGSRMRCHSACD.name: Exports Merchandise, Customs, current US$, millions, seas. adj.
DXGSRMRCHSACD.sourceNote: Merchandise (goods) exports,  free on board (f.o.b.), in current US$ millions, seasonally adjusted.

DXGSRMRCHNSKD.sourceOrganization: World Bank staff calculations based on Datastream and IMF International Finance Statistics data.
DXGSRMRCHNSKD.name: Exports Merchandise, Customs, constant US$, millions
DXGSRMRCHNSKD.sourceNote: Merchandise (goods) exports,  free on board (f.o.b.), in constant US$ millions not seasonally adjusted. The base year is 2005.

BXGSRGNFSKD.name: Exports GNFS, BOP, constant US$, millions
BXGSRGNFSKD.sourceNote: Exports of goods and services represent the value of all goods and other market services provided to the rest of the world. They include the value of merchandise, freight, insurance, transport, travel, royalties, license fees, and other services, such as communication, construction, financial, information, business, personal, and government services. They exclude compensation of employees and investment income (formerly called factor services) and transfer payments. Data are in constant US$, millions. The base year is 2005.

NYGDPDISCKN.sourceOrganization: World Bank staff calculations based on World Development Indicators data.
NYGDPDISCKN.name: GDP Discrepancy, constant LCU, millions
NYGDPDISCKN.sourceNote: A statistical discrepancy usually arises when the GDP components are estimated independently by industrial origin and by expenditure categories. This item represents the discrepancy in the use of resources (i.e., the estimate of GDP by expenditure categories). Data are in constant LCU millions. The base year varies by country.

BXGSRGNFSCD.name: Exports GNFS, BOP, current US$, millions
BXGSRGNFSCD.sourceNote: Exports of goods and services represent the value of all goods and other market services provided to the rest of the world. They include the value of merchandise, freight, insurance, transport, travel, royalties, license fees, and other services, such as communication, construction, financial, information, business, personal, and government services. They exclude compensation of employees and investment income (formerly called factor services) and transfer payments. Data are in current US$, millions.

DPANUSLCU.sourceOrganization: World Bank staff calculations based on Datastream and IMF International Finance Statistics data.
DPANUSLCU.name: Official exchange rate, LCU per USD, period average
DPANUSLCU.sourceNote: Official exchange rate refers to the exchange rate determined by national authorities or to the rate determined in the legally sanctioned exchange market. It is calculated as an annual average based on monthly averages (local currency units relative to the U.S. dollar).

XMKT.sourceOrganization: World Bank staff estimates and IMF Directions of Trade Statistics
XMKT.name: Export Market Growth Index
XMKT.sourceNote: The export market growth index measures the trade-weighted external demand for a country's merchandise goods exports based on the import demand in its export markets.

NEIMPGNFSKD.sourceOrganization: World Bank staff calculations based on World Development Indicators data.
NEIMPGNFSKD.name: Imports GNFS, constant US$, millions
NEIMPGNFSKD.sourceNote: Imports of goods and services represent the value of all goods and other market services received from the rest of the world. They include the value of merchandise, freight, insurance, transport, travel, royalties, license fees, and other services, such as communication, construction, financial, information, business, personal, and government services. They exclude compensation of employees and investment income (formerly called factor services) and transfer payments. Data are in constant US$, millions.  The base year is 2005.

NYGDPMKTPCN.sourceOrganization: World Bank staff calculations based on World Development Indicators data.
NYGDPMKTPCN.name: GDP, current LCU, millions
NYGDPMKTPCN.sourceNote: GDP at purchaser's prices is the sum of gross value added by all resident producers in the economy plus any product taxes and minus any subsidies not included in the value of the products. It is calculated without making deductions for depreciation of fabricated assets or for depletion and degradation of natural resources. Data are in current LCU millions.

DXGSRMRCHSAKD.sourceOrganization: World Bank staff calculations based on Datastream and IMF International Finance Statistics data.
DXGSRMRCHSAKD.name: Exports Merchandise, Customs, constant US$, millions, seas. adj.
DXGSRMRCHSAKD.sourceNote: Merchandise (goods) exports,  free on board (f.o.b.), in constant US$ millions, seasonally adjusted. The base year is 2005.

NECONGOVTXN.sourceOrganization: World Bank staff calculations based on World Development Indicators data.
NECONGOVTXN.name: Government Consumption deflator, LCU
NECONGOVTXN.sourceNote: The Government Consumption implicit deflator is the ratio of  Government Consumption in current local currency to  Government Consumption in constant local currency. The base year varies by country.

NEGDIFTOTCN.sourceOrganization: World Bank staff calculations based on World Development Indicators data.
NEGDIFTOTCN.name: Fixed Investment, current LCU, millions
NEGDIFTOTCN.sourceNote: Fixed investment includes land improvements (fences, ditches, drains, and so on); plant, machinery, and equipment purchases; and the construction of roads, railways, and the like, including schools, offices, hospitals, private residential dwellings, and commercial and industrial buildings. According to the 1993 SNA, net acquisitions of valuables are also considered capital formation. Data are in current LCU millions.

BMGSRMRCHXD.name: Imports Merchandise, BOP, deflator, US$
BMGSRMRCHXD.sourceNote: Imports Merchandise implicit deflator is the ratio of  Imports Merchandise in current local currency to  Imports Merchandise in constant local currency. The base year varies by country.

NEGDIFTOTCD.sourceOrganization: World Bank staff calculations based on World Development Indicators data.
NEGDIFTOTCD.name: Fixed Investment, current US$, millions
NEGDIFTOTCD.sourceNote: Fixed investment includes land improvements (fences, ditches, drains, and so on); plant, machinery, and equipment purchases; and the construction of roads, railways, and the like, including schools, offices, hospitals, private residential dwellings, and commercial and industrial buildings. According to the 1993 SNA, net acquisitions of valuables are also considered capital formation. Data are in current US$ millions.

NYGDPMKTPKP.sourceOrganization: World Bank staff calculations based on World Development Indicators data.
NYGDPMKTPKP.name: GDP, PPP basis, constant intl $, millions
NYGDPMKTPKP.sourceNote: PPP GDP is gross domestic product converted to international dollars using purchasing power parity rates. An international dollar has the same purchasing power over GDP as the U.S. dollar has in the United States. GDP is the sum of gross value added by all resident producers in the economy plus any product taxes and minus any subsidies not included in the value of the products. It is calculated without making deductions for depreciation of fabricated assets or for depletion and degradation of natural resources. Data are in constant 2005 international dollar millions.

EMBI.sourceOrganization: World Bank staff calculations based on Datastream data.
EMBI.name: J.P. Morgan Emerging Markets Bond Index (EMBI+)
EMBI.sourceNote: J.P. Morgan Emerging Markets Bond Index Plus is a market capitalization-weighted index based on bonds in emerging markets. the EMBI series which covers all of the external currency denomination debt of the emerging markets, as opposed to simply Brady Bond investment.  It is constructed with well-defined liquidity criteria to ensure that the index provides a fair and replicable benchmark. There are currently 31 instruments from 21 countries.

BMOTHCACD.name: Imports Other, BOP, current US$, millions
BMOTHCACD.sourceNote: Other imports provided by nonresidents to residents cover merchanting and other trade-related services; operational leasing services; and miscellaneous business, professional, and technical services. Data is in current US$ millions.

NYGDPMKTPCD.sourceOrganization: World Bank staff calculations based on World Development Indicators data.
NYGDPMKTPCD.name: GDP, current US$, millions
NYGDPMKTPCD.sourceNote: GDP at purchaser's prices is the sum of gross value added by all resident producers in the economy plus any product taxes and minus any subsidies not included in the value of the products. It is calculated without making deductions for depreciation of fabricated assets or for depletion and degradation of natural resources. Data are in current US$ millions.

NYGDPMKTPKD.sourceOrganization: World Bank staff calculations based on World Development Indicators data.
NYGDPMKTPKD.name: GDP, constant US$, millions
NYGDPMKTPKD.sourceNote: GDP at purchaser's prices is the sum of gross value added by all resident producers in the economy plus any product taxes and minus any subsidies not included in the value of the products. It is calculated without making deductions for depreciation of fabricated assets or for depletion and degradation of natural resources. Data are in constant US$ millions.  The base year is 2005.

NYGDPMKTPCP.sourceOrganization: World Bank staff calculations based on World Development Indicators data.
NYGDPMKTPCP.name: GDP, PPP basis, current intl $, millions
NYGDPMKTPCP.sourceNote: PPP GDP is gross domestic product converted to international dollars using purchasing power parity rates. An international dollar has the same purchasing power over GDP as the U.S. dollar has in the United States. GDP is the sum of gross value added by all resident producers in the economy plus any product taxes and minus any subsidies not included in the value of the products. It is calculated without making deductions for depreciation of fabricated assets or for depletion and degradation of natural resources. Data are in current international dollar millions.

BNGSRGNFSKD.name: Net Exports GNFS, BOP, constant US$, millions
BNGSRGNFSKD.sourceNote: The net exports of goods and non-factor services (GNFS). Data is in constant US$ millions with 2005 as the base year.

NYGDPMKTPKN.sourceOrganization: World Bank staff calculations based on World Development Indicators data.
NYGDPMKTPKN.name: GDP, constant LCU, millions
NYGDPMKTPKN.sourceNote: GDP at purchaser's prices is the sum of gross value added by all resident producers in the economy plus any product taxes and minus any subsidies not included in the value of the products. It is calculated without making deductions for depreciation of fabricated assets or for depletion and degradation of natural resources. Data are in constant LCU millions. The base year varies by country.

BNOTHCACD.name: Net Exports Other, BOP, current US$, millions
BNOTHCACD.sourceNote: Other Net exports provided by residents to nonresidents cover merchanting and other trade-related services; operational leasing services; and miscellaneous business, professional, and technical services.

IMPCOV.sourceOrganization: World Bank staff calculations based on Datastream data.
IMPCOV.name: Foreign Reserves, Months Import Cover, Goods
IMPCOV.sourceNote: The stock of international reserves is expressed as the number of months of financing-coverage it represents for the given country's imports of merchandise goods.

NECONPRVTXN.sourceOrganization: World Bank staff calculations based on World Development Indicators data.
NECONPRVTXN.name: Private Consumption deflator, LCU
NECONPRVTXN.sourceNote: The Private Consumption implicit deflator is the ratio of  Private Consumption in current local currency to  Private Consumption in constant local currency. The base year varies by country.

IPTOTSAKD.sourceOrganization: World Bank staff calculations based on Datastream data.
IPTOTSAKD.name: Industrial Production, constant US$, seas. adj.
IPTOTSAKD.sourceNote: An economic indicator that measures changes in output for the industrial sector of the economy. The industrial sector includes manufacturing, mining, and utilities. Data is in constant US$, seasonally adjusted. The base year is 2005.

DXGSRMRCHNSCD.sourceOrganization: World Bank staff calculations based on Datastream and IMF International Finance Statistics data.
DXGSRMRCHNSCD.name: Exports Merchandise, Customs, current US$, millions
DXGSRMRCHNSCD.sourceNote: Merchandise (goods) exports,  free on board (f.o.b.), in current US$ millions, not seasonally adjusted.

BXGSRNFSVXD.name: Exports Services, BOP, deflator, US$
BXGSRNFSVXD.sourceNote: The Exports Services implicit deflator is the ratio of Exports Services in current local currency to Exports Services in constant local currency. The base year varies by country.

NEGDISTKBCD.sourceOrganization: World Bank staff calculations based on World Development Indicators data.
NEGDISTKBCD.name: Change in Inventories, current US$, millions
NEGDISTKBCD.sourceNote: Inventories are stocks of goods held by firms to meet temporary or unexpected fluctuations in production or sales, and "work in progress." Data is in current US$, millions

NEGDISTKBCN.sourceOrganization: World Bank staff calculations based on World Development Indicators data.
NEGDISTKBCN.name: Change in Inventories, current LCU, millions
NEGDISTKBCN.sourceNote: Inventories are stocks of goods held by firms to meet temporary or unexpected fluctuations in production or sales, and "work in progress." Data is in curent LCU, millions.

NEIMPGNFSKN.sourceOrganization: World Bank staff calculations based on World Development Indicators data.
NEIMPGNFSKN.name: Imports GNFS, constant LCU, millions
NEIMPGNFSKN.sourceNote: Imports of goods and services represent the value of all goods and other market services received from the rest of the world. They include the value of merchandise, freight, insurance, transport, travel, royalties, license fees, and other services, such as communication, construction, financial, information, business, personal, and government services. They exclude compensation of employees and investment income (formerly called factor services) and transfer payments. Data are in constant LCU, millions. The base year varies by country.

GGBALOVRLCD.sourceOrganization: World Bank staff calculations based on World Economic Outlook data.
GGBALOVRLCD.name: General Govt. Balance, current US$, millions
GGBALOVRLCD.sourceNote: General government balance is the net balance of federal, state and local receipts minus outlays. Data is presented in current US$ millions.

DMGSRMRCHNSCD.sourceOrganization: World Bank staff calculations based on Datastream and IMF International Finance Statistics data.
DMGSRMRCHNSCD.name: Imports Merchandise, Customs, current US$, millions
DMGSRMRCHNSCD.sourceNote: Merchandise (goods) imports, cost, insurance and freight basis (c.i.f.), in current US$ millions, not seasonally adjusted.

GDPPCKD.sourceOrganization: World Bank staff calculations based on World Development Indicators data.
GDPPCKD.name: GDP per Capita, constant US$, millions
GDPPCKD.sourceNote: GDP per capita is gross domestic product divided by midyear population. GDP at purchaser's prices is the sum of gross value added by all resident producers in the economy plus any product taxes and minus any subsidies not included in the value of the products. It is calculated without making deductions for depreciation of fabricated assets or for depletion and degradation of natural resources. Data are in constant US$. The base year is 2005.

DSTKMKTXN.sourceOrganization: World Bank staff calculations based on Datastream and IMF International Finance Statistics data.
DSTKMKTXN.name: Stock Markets, LCU
DSTKMKTXN.sourceNote: Local equity market index valued in local currency unit (LCU) terms

GGBALOVRLCN.sourceOrganization: World Bank staff calculations based on World Economic Outlook data.
GGBALOVRLCN.name: General Govt. Balance, current LCU, millions
GGBALOVRLCN.sourceNote: General government balance is the net balance of federal, state and local receipts minus outlays. Data is presented in current LCU millions.

SPPOPTOTL.sourceOrganization: United Nations Population Statistics and World Bank staff calculations
SPPOPTOTL.name: Population, millions
SPPOPTOTL.sourceNote: Total population is based on the de facto definition of population, which counts all residents regardless of legal status or citizenship--except for refugees not permanently settled in the country of asylum, who are generally considered part of the population of their country of origin.

NEGDITOTLXN.sourceOrganization: World Bank staff calculations based on World Development Indicators data.
NEGDITOTLXN.name: Total Investment deflator, LCU
NEGDITOTLXN.sourceNote: The Total Investment implicit deflator is the ratio of Total Invesment in current local currency to Total Investment in constant local currency. The base year varies by country.

DXGSRMRCHNSXD.sourceOrganization: World Bank staff calculations based on Datastream and IMF International Finance Statistics data.
DXGSRMRCHNSXD.name: Exports Merchandise, Customs, Price, US$
DXGSRMRCHNSXD.sourceNote: The price index of Merchandise (goods) exports,  free on board (f.o.b.), in currrent US$ millions. Not seasonally adjusted.

BMGSRNFSVCD.name: Imports Services, BOP, current US$, millions
BMGSRNFSVCD.sourceNote: Imports of services represent the value of all market services received from the rest of the world. They include the value of services, such as communication, construction, financial, information, business, personal, and government services. They exclude compensation of employees and investment income (formerly called factor services) and transfer payments. Data are in current US$ millions.

BMGSRNFSVKD.name: Imports Services, BOP, constant US$, millions
BMGSRNFSVKD.sourceNote: Imports of services represent the value of all market services received from the rest of the world. They include the value of services, such as communication, construction, financial, information, business, personal, and government services. They exclude compensation of employees and investment income (formerly called factor services) and transfer payments. Data are in constant US$ millions.

IR10Y.sourceOrganization: World Bank staff calculations based on Datastream data.
IR10Y.name: Interest Rates (10YR)
IR10Y.sourceNote: A country's bond yield with a 10 year maturity

CPTOTSAXMZGY.sourceOrganization: World Bank staff calculations based on Datastream data.
CPTOTSAXMZGY.name: CPI Price, % y-o-y, median weighted, seas. adj.
CPTOTSAXMZGY.sourceNote: Median inflation rate calculated for geographical aggregates (regions, world, etc) of the annual percent change of the CPI. Data is seasonally adjusted.

NEEXPGNFSCD.sourceOrganization: World Bank staff calculations based on World Development Indicators data.
NEEXPGNFSCD.name: Exports GNFS, current US$, millions
NEEXPGNFSCD.sourceNote: Exports of goods and services represent the value of all goods and other market services provided to the rest of the world. They include the value of merchandise, freight, insurance, transport, travel, royalties, license fees, and other services, such as communication, construction, financial, information, business, personal, and government services. They exclude compensation of employees and investment income (formerly called factor services) and transfer payments. Data are in current US$, millions.

LIBOR6M.sourceOrganization: World Bank staff calculations based on Datastream data.
LIBOR6M.name: London Interbank Offered 6-month rates (LIBOR)
LIBOR6M.sourceNote: LIBOR stands for London Interbank Offered Rate. It's the rate of interest at which banks offer to lend money to one another in the wholesale money markets in London. It is a standard financial index used in international capital markets. The data is for the 6 Month LIBOR rate.

DMGSRMRCHNSKD.sourceOrganization: World Bank staff calculations based on Datastream and IMF International Finance Statistics data.
DMGSRMRCHNSKD.name: Imports Merchandise, Customs, constant US$, millions
DMGSRMRCHNSKD.sourceNote: Merchandise (goods) imports, cost, insurance and freight basis (c.i.f.), in constant US$ millions, not seasonally adjusted. The base year is 2005.

CPTOTSAXN.sourceOrganization: World Bank staff calculations based on Datastream data.
CPTOTSAXN.name: CPI Price, nominal, seas. adj.
CPTOTSAXN.sourceNote: The consumer price index reflects the change in prices for the average consumer of a constant basket of consumer goods. Data is in nominal terms and seasonally adjusted.

NEGDIFTOTKD.sourceOrganization: World Bank staff calculations based on World Development Indicators data.
NEGDIFTOTKD.name: Fixed Investment, constant US$, millions
NEGDIFTOTKD.sourceNote: Fixed investment includes land improvements (fences, ditches, drains, and so on); plant, machinery, and equipment purchases; and the construction of roads, railways, and the like, including schools, offices, hospitals, private residential dwellings, and commercial and industrial buildings. According to the 1993 SNA, net acquisitions of valuables are also considered capital formation. Data are in constant US$ millions.  The base year is 2005.

NEEXPGNFSCN.sourceOrganization: World Bank staff calculations based on World Development Indicators data.
NEEXPGNFSCN.name: Exports GNFS, current LCU, millions
NEEXPGNFSCN.sourceNote: Exports of goods and services represent the value of all goods and other market services provided to the rest of the world. They include the value of merchandise, freight, insurance, transport, travel, royalties, license fees, and other services, such as communication, construction, financial, information, business, personal, and government services. They exclude compensation of employees and investment income (formerly called factor services) and transfer payments. Data are in current LCU, millions.

TOTRESV.sourceOrganization: World Bank staff calculations based on Datastream data.
TOTRESV.name: Total Reserves
TOTRESV.sourceNote: Total reserves comprise holdings of monetary gold, special drawing rights, reserves of IMF members held by the IMF, and holdings of foreign exchange under the control of monetary authorities.

NEGDIFTOTKN.sourceOrganization: World Bank staff calculations based on World Development Indicators data.
NEGDIFTOTKN.name: Fixed Investment, constant LCU, millions
NEGDIFTOTKN.sourceNote: Fixed investment includes land improvements (fences, ditches, drains, and so on); plant, machinery, and equipment purchases; and the construction of roads, railways, and the like, including schools, offices, hospitals, private residential dwellings, and commercial and industrial buildings. According to the 1993 SNA, net acquisitions of valuables are also considered capital formation. Data are in constant LCU millions. The base year varies by country.

NYGDPMKTPXN.sourceOrganization: World Bank staff calculations based on World Development Indicators data.
NYGDPMKTPXN.name: GDP deflator, LCU
NYGDPMKTPXN.sourceNote: The GDP implicit deflator is the ratio of GDP in current local currency to GDP in constant local currency. The base year varies by country.

GGBALOVRLCD_.sourceOrganization: World Bank staff calculations based on World Economic Outlook data.
GGBALOVRLCD_.name: General Govt. Balance, %GDP
GGBALOVRLCD_.sourceNote: General government balance is the net balance of federal, state and local receipts minus outlays. Data is presented as a % of GDP.

PMKEY.name: Merchandise Import Price Index, US$ (Keyfitz-Savescu)
PMKEY.sourceNote: A comprehensive merchandise import price index calculated using a simple equilibrium model  that uses pooled regressions and incorporates trade of over 200 countries in 33 commodities (comprising most of the weight of the World Bank’s primary commodity coverage).The base year is 2005.

NYGDPDISCCN.sourceOrganization: World Bank staff calculations based on World Development Indicators data.
NYGDPDISCCN.name: GDP Discrepancy, current LCU, millions
NYGDPDISCCN.sourceNote: A statistical discrepancy usually arises when the GDP components are estimated independently by industrial origin and by expenditure categories. This item represents the discrepancy in the use of resources (i.e., the estimate of GDP by expenditure categories). Data are in current LCU millions.

BNGSRGNFSCD.name: Net Exports GNFS, BOP, current US$, millions
BNGSRGNFSCD.sourceNote: The net exports of goods and non-factor services (GNFS). Data is in current US$ millions.

M2BYR.sourceOrganization: World Bank staff calculations based on Datastream data.
M2BYR.name: Broad Money (M2) to foreign reserves, ratio
M2BYR.sourceNote: A measure of the money supply that includes more than just physical money such as currency and coins (also termed narrow money). It is generally includes demand deposits at commercial banks, and any monies held in easily accessible accounts. Components broad money are still very liquid, and non-cash components can usually be converted into cash very easily. M2 includes currency and coins, and deposits in checking accounts, savings accounts and small time deposits, overnight repos at commercial banks, and non-institutional money market accounts. This is the main measure of the money supply, and is the economic indicator usually used to assess the amount of liquidity in the economy, as it is relatively easy to track. The data is expressed as a ratio of the foreign reserves.

NYGDPDISCCD.sourceOrganization: World Bank staff calculations based on World Development Indicators data.
NYGDPDISCCD.name: GDP Discrepancy, current US$, millions
NYGDPDISCCD.sourceNote: A statistical discrepancy usually arises when the GDP components are estimated independently by industrial origin and by expenditure categories. This item represents the discrepancy in the use of resources (i.e., the estimate of GDP by expenditure categories). Data are in current US$ millions.

NYGDPDISCKD.sourceOrganization: World Bank staff calculations based on World Development Indicators data.
NYGDPDISCKD.name: GDP Discrepancy, constant US$, millions
NYGDPDISCKD.sourceNote: A statistical discrepancy usually arises when the GDP components are estimated independently by industrial origin and by expenditure categories. This item represents the discrepancy in the use of resources (i.e., the estimate of GDP by expenditure categories). Data are in constant US$ millions.  The base year is 2005.

BNGSRMRCHKD.name: Trade Balance, BOP, constant US$, millions
BNGSRMRCHKD.sourceNote: Trade Balance is the sum of exports minus imports of merchandise goods. Data is in constant US$, millions.

BNCABFUNDCD.name: Current Account Balance, current US$, millions
BNCABFUNDCD.sourceNote: Current account balance is the sum of net exports of goods, services, net income, and net current transfers. Data is in current US$ millions

CPTOTNSXNZGY.sourceOrganization: World Bank staff calculations based on Datastream data.
CPTOTNSXNZGY.name: CPI Price, % y-o-y, nominal
CPTOTNSXNZGY.sourceNote: The consumer price index reflects the change in prices for the average consumer of a constant basket of consumer goods. Data is in nominal percentage terms, measured on a year-on-year basis, and not seasonally adjusted.

IPTOTNSKD.sourceOrganization: World Bank staff calculations based on Datastream data.
IPTOTNSKD.name: Industrial Production, constant US$
IPTOTNSKD.sourceNote: An economic indicator that measures changes in output for the industrial sector of the economy. The industrial sector includes manufacturing, mining, and utilities. Data is in constant US$, and not seasonally adjusted. The base year is 2005.

BNGSRMRCHCD.name: Trade Balance, BOP, current US$, millions
BNGSRMRCHCD.sourceNote: Trade Balance is the sum of exports minus imports of merchandise goods. Data is in current US$, millions.

NEIMPGNFSCD.sourceOrganization: World Bank staff calculations based on World Development Indicators data.
NEIMPGNFSCD.name: Imports GNFS, current US$, millions
NEIMPGNFSCD.sourceNote: Imports of goods and services represent the value of all goods and other market services received from the rest of the world. They include the value of merchandise, freight, insurance, transport, travel, royalties, license fees, and other services, such as communication, construction, financial, information, business, personal, and government services. They exclude compensation of employees and investment income (formerly called factor services) and transfer payments. Data are in current US$, millions.

NEGDISTKBKN.sourceOrganization: World Bank staff calculations based on World Development Indicators data.
NEGDISTKBKN.name: Change in Inventories, constant LCU, millions
NEGDISTKBKN.sourceNote: Inventories are stocks of goods held by firms to meet temporary or unexpected fluctuations in production or sales, and "work in progress." Data is in constant LCU, millions. The base year varies by country.

NEIMPGNFSCN.sourceOrganization: World Bank staff calculations based on World Development Indicators data.
NEIMPGNFSCN.name: Imports GNFS, current LCU, millions
NEIMPGNFSCN.sourceNote: Imports of goods and services represent the value of all goods and other market services received from the rest of the world. They include the value of merchandise, freight, insurance, transport, travel, royalties, license fees, and other services, such as communication, construction, financial, information, business, personal, and government services. They exclude compensation of employees and investment income (formerly called factor services) and transfer payments. Data are in current LCU, millions.

NEGDISTKBKD.sourceOrganization: World Bank staff calculations based on World Development Indicators data.
NEGDISTKBKD.name: Change in Inventories, constant US$, millions
NEGDISTKBKD.sourceNote: Inventories are stocks of goods held by firms to meet temporary or unexpected fluctuations in production or sales, and "work in progress." Data is in constant US$ millions.  The base year is 2005.

BXGSRGNFSXD.name: Exports GNFS, BOP, deflator, US$
BXGSRGNFSXD.sourceNote: The Exports GNFS implicit deflator is the ratio of Exports GNFS in current local currency to  Exports GNFS in constant local currency. The base year varies by country.

NYGDPDISCXN.sourceOrganization: World Bank staff calculations based on World Development Indicators data.
NYGDPDISCXN.name: GDP Discrepancy deflator, LCU
NYGDPDISCXN.sourceNote: The GDP Discrepancy implicit deflator is the ratio of GDP Discrepancy in current local currency to GDP Discrepancy in constant local currency. The base year varies by country.

BXOTHCACD.name: Exports Other, BOP, current US$, millions
BXOTHCACD.sourceNote: Other exports provided by residents to nonresidents cover merchanting and other trade-related services; operational leasing services; and miscellaneous business, professional, and technical services.

PXKEY.name: Merchandise Export Price Index, US$ (Keyfitz-Savescu)
PXKEY.sourceNote: A comprehensive merchandise export price index calculated using a simple equilibrium model  that uses pooled regressions and incorporates trade of over 200 countries in 33 commodities (comprising most of the weight of the World Bank’s primary commodity coverage).The base year is 2005.

NEGDISTKBXN.sourceOrganization: World Bank staff calculations based on World Development Indicators data.
NEGDISTKBXN.name: Change in Inventories deflator, LCU
NEGDISTKBXN.sourceNote: The Change in Inventories implicit deflator is the ratio of Change in Inventories in current local currency to Change in Inventories in constant local currency. The base year varies by country.

TOT.sourceOrganization: World Bank staff calculations based on Datastream data.
TOT.name: Terms of Trade
TOT.sourceNote: The terms of trade effect equals capacity to import less exports of goods and services.

DPANUSIFS.sourceOrganization: World Bank staff calculations based on Datastream and IMF International Finance Statistics data.
DPANUSIFS.name: Exchange rate (IFS), LCU per USD, period average
DPANUSIFS.sourceNote: Exchange rate refers to the rate determined in the legally sanctioned exchange market. It is calculated as an annual average based on monthly averages (local currency units relative to the U.S. dollar).

BXGSRNFSVCD.name: Exports Services, BOP, current US$, millions
BXGSRNFSVCD.sourceNote: Exports of services represent the value of all market services provided to the rest of the world. They include the value of services, such as communication, construction, financial, information, business, personal, and government services. They exclude compensation of employees and investment income (formerly called factor services) and transfer payments. Data are in current US$ millions.

BMGSRNFSVXD.name: Imports Services, BOP, deflator, US$
BMGSRNFSVXD.sourceNote: The Imports Services implicit deflator is the ratio of  Imports Services in current local currency to  Imports Services in constant local currency. The base year varies by country.

NEIMPGNFSXN.sourceOrganization: World Bank staff calculations based on World Development Indicators data.
NEIMPGNFSXN.name: Imports GNFS deflator, LCU
NEIMPGNFSXN.sourceNote: The Imports GNFS implicit deflator is the ratio of  Imports GNFS in current local currency to Imports GNFS in constant local currency. The base year varies by country.

NECONPRVTCN.sourceOrganization: World Bank staff calculations based on World Development Indicators data.
NECONPRVTCN.name: Private Consumption, current LCU, millions
NECONPRVTCN.sourceNote: Private Consumption is the market value of all goods and services, including durable products (such as cars, washing machines, and home computers), purchased by households. It excludes purchases of dwellings but includes imputed rent for owner-occupied dwellings. It also includes payments and fees to governments to obtain permits and licenses. Here, household consumption expenditure includes the expenditures of nonprofit institutions serving households, even when reported separately by the country. Data are in current LCU, millions.

NYGDPPOTLKD.sourceOrganization: World Bank staff calculations based on World Development Indicators data.
NYGDPPOTLKD.name: GDP Potential, constant US$, millions
NYGDPPOTLKD.sourceNote: Potential GDP is the estimated level of total output when the economy is operating at natural rate of unemployment, presented in constant US$, millions. The base year is 2005.

IRSPREAD.sourceOrganization: World Bank staff calculations based on Datastream data.
IRSPREAD.name: Sovereign Bond Interest Rate Spreads, basis points over US Treasuries

NECONPRVTCD.sourceOrganization: World Bank staff calculations based on World Development Indicators data.
NECONPRVTCD.name: Private Consumption, current US$, millions
NECONPRVTCD.sourceNote: Private Consumption is the market value of all goods and services, including durable products (such as cars, washing machines, and home computers), purchased by households. It excludes purchases of dwellings but includes imputed rent for owner-occupied dwellings. It also includes payments and fees to governments to obtain permits and licenses. Here, household consumption expenditure includes the expenditures of nonprofit institutions serving households, even when reported separately by the country. Data are in current US$, millions.

BXGSRMRCHKD.name: Exports Merchandise, BOP, constant US$, millions
BXGSRMRCHKD.sourceNote: Merchandise exports show the f.o.b. value of goods provided to the rest of the world valued in constant US$ dollars. The base year is 2005.

DMGSRMRCHNSXD.sourceOrganization: World Bank staff calculations based on Datastream and IMF International Finance Statistics data.
DMGSRMRCHNSXD.name: Imports Merchandise, Customs, Price, US$
DMGSRMRCHNSXD.sourceNote: The price index of Merchandise (goods) imports, cost, insurance and freight basis (c.i.f.), in constant US$ millions, not seasonally adjusted. The base year is 2005.

NEEXPGNFSKD.sourceOrganization: World Bank staff calculations based on World Development Indicators data.
NEEXPGNFSKD.name: Exports GNFS, constant US$, millions
NEEXPGNFSKD.sourceNote: Exports of goods and services represent the value of all goods and other market services provided to the rest of the world. They include the value of merchandise, freight, insurance, transport, travel, royalties, license fees, and other services, such as communication, construction, financial, information, business, personal, and government services. They exclude compensation of employees and investment income (formerly called factor services) and transfer payments. Data are in constant US$, millions.  The base year is 2005.

PANUSATLS.sourceOrganization: World Bank staff calculations based on World Development Indicators data.
PANUSATLS.name: DEC exchange rate (LCU per US$)
PANUSATLS.sourceNote: Exchange rate refers to the exchange rate determined by the Development Economics Group through the Atlas Method, which is an alternative rate used to smooth fluctuations in prices and exchange rates by a special method of conversion used by the World Bank. This applies a conversion factor that averages the exchange rate for a given year and the two preceding years, adjusted for differences in rates of inflation between the country, and through 2000, the G-5 countries (France, Germany, Japan, the United Kingdom, and the United States). From 2001, these countries include the Euro area, Japan, the United Kingdom, and the United States.

BXGSRNFSVKD.name: Exports Services, BOP, constant US$, millions
BXGSRNFSVKD.sourceNote: Exports of services represent the value of all market services provided to the rest of the world. They include the value of services, such as communication, construction, financial, information, business, personal, and government services. They exclude compensation of employees and investment income (formerly called factor services) and transfer payments. Data are in constant US$ millions. The base year is 2005.

NEEXPGNFSKN.sourceOrganization: World Bank staff calculations based on World Development Indicators data.
NEEXPGNFSKN.name: Exports GNFS, constant LCU, millions
NEEXPGNFSKN.sourceNote: Exports of goods and services represent the value of all goods and other market services provided to the rest of the world. They include the value of merchandise, freight, insurance, transport, travel, royalties, license fees, and other services, such as communication, construction, financial, information, business, personal, and government services. They exclude compensation of employees and investment income (formerly called factor services) and transfer payments. Data are in constant LCU, millions.

NECONPRVTKN.sourceOrganization: World Bank staff calculations based on World Development Indicators data.
NECONPRVTKN.name: Private Consumption, constant LCU, millions
NECONPRVTKN.sourceNote: Private Consumption is the market value of all goods and services, including durable products (such as cars, washing machines, and home computers), purchased by households. It excludes purchases of dwellings but includes imputed rent for owner-occupied dwellings. It also includes payments and fees to governments to obtain permits and licenses. Here, household consumption expenditure includes the expenditures of nonprofit institutions serving households, even when reported separately by the country. Data are in constant LCU, millions. The base year varies by country.

NEER.sourceOrganization: World Bank staff calculations based on Datastream and IMF International Finance Statistics data.
NEER.name: Nominal Effecive Exchange Rate
NEER.sourceNote: A measure of the value of a currency against a weighted average of several foreign currencies

DMGSRMRCHSAXD.sourceOrganization: World Bank staff calculations based on Datastream and IMF International Finance Statistics data.
DMGSRMRCHSAXD.name: Imports Merchandise, Customs, Price, US$, seas. adj.
DMGSRMRCHSAXD.sourceNote: The price index of Merchandise (goods) imports, cost, insurance and freight basis (c.i.f.), in constant US$ millions, seasonally adjusted. The base year is 2005.

NEEXPGNFSXN.sourceOrganization: World Bank staff calculations based on World Development Indicators data.
NEEXPGNFSXN.name: Exports GNFS deflator, LCU
NEEXPGNFSXN.sourceNote: The Exports GNFS implicit deflator is the ratio of  Exports GNFS in current local currency to Exports GNFS in constant local currency. The base year varies by country.

BMGSRGNFSXD.name: Imports GNFS, BOP, deflator, US$
BMGSRGNFSXD.sourceNote: The Imports GNFS implicit deflator is the ratio of  Imports of goods and non-factor services (GNFS) in current local currency to  Imports GNFS in constant local currency. The base year varies by country.

BNCABFUNDCD_.name: Current Account Balance, %GDP
BNCABFUNDCD_.sourceNote: Current account balance is the sum of net exports of goods, services, net income, and net current transfers. Data is presented as a share of nominal GDP.

BXGSRMRCHCD.name: Exports Merchandise, BOP, current US$, millions
BXGSRMRCHCD.sourceNote: Merchandise exports show the f.o.b. value of goods provided to the rest of the world valued in current US$ dollars.

BMGSRGNFSKD.name: Imports GNFS, BOP, constant US$, millions
BMGSRGNFSKD.sourceNote: Imports of goods and non-factor services (GNFS) represent the value of all goods and other market services received from the rest of the world. They include the value of merchandise, freight, insurance, transport, travel, royalties, license fees, and other services, such as communication, construction, financial, information, business, personal, and government services. They exclude compensation of employees and investment income (formerly called factor services) and transfer payments. Data are in constat US$ millions

DMGSRMRCHSAKD.sourceOrganization: World Bank staff calculations based on Datastream and IMF International Finance Statistics data.
DMGSRMRCHSAKD.name: Imports Merchandise, Customs, constant US$, millions, seas. adj.
DMGSRMRCHSAKD.sourceNote: Merchandise (goods) exports, cost, insurance and freight basis (c.i.f.), in constant US$ millions, seasonally adjusted. The base year is 2005.

BMGSRGNFSCD.name: Imports GNFS, BOP, current US$, millions
BMGSRGNFSCD.sourceNote: Imports of goods and non-factor services (GNFS) represent the value of all goods and other market services received from the rest of the world. They include the value of merchandise, freight, insurance, transport, travel, royalties, license fees, and other services, such as communication, construction, financial, information, business, personal, and government services. They exclude compensation of employees and investment income (formerly called factor services) and transfer payments. Data are in current US$ millions

M2MULT.sourceOrganization: World Bank staff calculations based on Datastream data.
M2MULT.name: Broad Money (M2) to monetary base, ratio (M2 multiplier)
M2MULT.sourceNote: A measure of the money supply that includes more than just physical money such as currency and coins (also termed narrow money). It is generally includes demand deposits at commercial banks, and any monies held in easily accessible accounts. Components broad money are still very liquid, and non-cash components can usually be converted into cash very easily. M2 includes currency and coins, and deposits in checking accounts, savings accounts and small time deposits, overnight repos at commercial banks, and non-institutional money market accounts. This is the main measure of the money supply, and is the economic indicator usually used to assess the amount of liquidity in the economy, as it is relatively easy to track. The data is expressed as a ratio of the monetary base.

DMGSRMRCHSACD.sourceOrganization: World Bank staff calculations based on Datastream and IMF International Finance Statistics data.
DMGSRMRCHSACD.name: Imports Merchandise, Customs, current US$, millions, seas. adj.
DMGSRMRCHSACD.sourceNote: Merchandise (goods) imports, cost, insurance and freight basis (c.i.f.), in current US$ millions, seasonally adjusted.

NYGDPMKTPXP.sourceOrganization: World Bank staff calculations based on World Development Indicators data.
NYGDPMKTPXP.name: GDP, PPP basis, deflator
NYGDPMKTPXP.sourceNote: The PPP Based GDP implicit deflator is the ratio of PPP Based GDP in current currency to PPP Based GDP in constant currency. The base year is 2005.
